title: The UK has seen a mass influx of this beautiful butterfly this year – here's why
text:
From House Beautiful

Almost half a million painted lady butterfly species have been spotted in the UK as part of the annual Big Butterfly Count (which ran from Friday 19th July to 11th August).

The Butterfly Conservation charity have dubbed 2019 'the painted lady summer' as 420,841 butterflies were spotted by those taking part in the hunt.

In fact, this year is experiencing a bigger influx than ever before of the beautiful orange and black butterflies, as millions have travelled north from Europe. Naturalist and Springwatch presenter Chris Packham has described it as a 'promising' sign for the species.

'Painted Lady came top overall in big butterfly count 2019, and was also the most numerous species recorded in each of England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. Its previous best performance in the Count was coming 13th in 2018 and it is typically one of the least frequently seen of the 19 target species,' explains the results.

The last mass painted lady migration in 2008 saw 11 million of the species grace UK shores, but this year has experienced even higher figures.

The Big Butterfly Count results 2019

Painted Lady, 420,841 Peacock, 207,814 Small White, 179,715

Gatekeeper, 161,987 Large White, 138,671

Meadow Brown, 110,858 Red Admiral, 91,146

Small Tortoiseshell, 70,704 Speckled Wood, 33,015

Green-veined White, 32,965 Comma, 32,137 Ringlet, 31,580 Common Blue, 23,604 Six-spot Burnet, 12,483 Holly Blue, 11,814 Small Copper, 10,905 Marbled White, 10,402 Brimstone, 9,261 Silver Y, 5,662

Chris Packham describes these mass butterfly migrations as 'one of the wonders of the natural world,' reports the BBC. He says that painted ladies can fly up to 30mph through their 7,500mile migration from Africa to the Arctic circle and back again.
